class_notes:
Prerequisite requirement: ENVS 120, ENVS 130 or ENVS 140.


This course introduces the concept of environmental justice from a geographical, political, and environmental science perspective. It focuses on the systemic and historical roots of environmental injustices both within America and on a global scale. We will pay specific attention to injustices related to toxic waste, clean water access, tree canopy distribution, housing, climate change, renewable energy, food, occupational hazards, and health outcomes. We will examine how these inequities disproportionately affect Blacks, Indigenous, immigrants, and communities of color. We will also examine how social movements have responded to these injustices, including how they challenge systems and structures that perpetuate environmental racism and socio-economic inequalities. Students will learn about modern methods and tools for measuring environmental injustices as well as strategies, policies, and practical solutions for promoting environmental justice in different geographical and ecological contexts.
course_description: Variable topics that are offered as irregular courses. Past course topics have included: Finding Place: Technology, Stories, and the Environment; Introduction to Botany; Environment, Health, and Development; Conservation and Development; Booms and Busts in Resources of Georgia; and Paleoecology.
